utterances: Well, that's true.
Some people just don't learn.
And Pacman Jones, in this case, sitting out - you'd think sitting out a year from the NFL that he had learned his lesson.
That, you know, he wasn't getting any income coming in.
Got suspended, realized this is his - you know, hopefully that he had some perspective sitting out for a year.
But obviously what allegedly happened Wednesday night, Pacman is - could be, you know, in trouble again.
Could be in trouble again for sure.
Another guy who was in trouble just recently with his team, D-Will, Plaxico Burress of the New York Giants.
He was suspended for two weeks including - he was suspended including last week's game against the Seahawks.
Now, he was AWOL, and said that he had had to take his kid to school.
Didn't call anybody to let them know.
And then after the suspension, he said no, I'm not sorry, but the next time I will at least pick up a telephone.
Now, the Giants won without him.
So what's going on with the G-man?
I don't think anything's going on with the G-man.
As a matter of fact, all of his teammates love him.
They support him and they don't find that there's a problem with him.
Actually the problem is more, to me at least, a media creation than it is in-house creation.
Plaxico Burress is known within the locker room as being one of those tardy people who's - you know, and people - some people are like that.
They're just late people.
And he is one of those people.
He's constantly late for meetings, constantly forgetting to call the offices, et cetera.
This is Dante's Inferno, Bill.
There's no way to sugarcoat it.
This is the most horrible thing I've ever seen in a civilized nation.
And in this case, he's estranged from his wife, his son was having a problem, he needed to get to school, et cetera, as you said.
He did what he had to do.
Yes, he forgot to call the team.
He's been fined over and over and over for this type of thing.
It's nothing new for him.
And his reaction to it actually spoke to that fact that it's really nothing new and no big deal.
It's all water under the bridge and everything's OK.
What is it, Greg Lee, about these wide receivers?
T.O., Randy Moss, Ocho Cinco?
I mean, these guys, they are like crazy?
Why is that?
Receivers, you know, they're the kind of guys who, they thrive in the spotlight.
They want the ball.
They feel like they need the ball.
It's a very extravagant position.
I love T.O., I love Ocho Cinco.
I loved the wide receiver position.
But at the same time, a lot of these receivers, yeah they do get, you know - get under the skin of some fans and even some of their teammates.
But at the same time, T.O is very passionate.
T.O.
gets out on the field, he practices hard.
He plays real hard.
He goes all out.
Ocho Cinco is the same way.

So although some of the receivers get a bad rap, but the reality is that they're really hard workers and they wouldn't be the players that they are today if they didn't put any hard work or any time to it.
So I really look at that more so - the flamboyance of the receiver position.
But it is what it is with that position.
You've got to accept it and within a case of the T.Os and the Ocho Cincos and the Plaxico Burresses, Plaxico caught a winning touch on the Super Bowl.
T.O.
constantly produces.
So I have no problem with it.
You're right.
High risk.
High reward.
All right guys, we're going to end sports bloggers this week on this topic.
It is October, which means this is the one month of the year where every major sport is going, including the big four, baseball, football, basketball even hockey for crying out loud.
Plus college football.
How many games do you guys watch a week?
How many TV sets do you have going?
I've got about 30 seconds for you, D-Will, on that.
I actually have three televisions, DirectTV, and a full package for everything.
So - and, of course, I'm sitting with a laptop as well.
So I'm watching sports all the time.
Really?
What about you, Greg?
How many TVs going on your house at the same time?
Three with TiVo and plus I have all the packages.
And when I'm not home, I can get the DirectTV NFL package on my laptop.
So when I'm away, I can watch football on my laptop.
So it's NFL.
I feel you guys.
I have one station on in my office, another station on in the family room, and another station on in the kitchen.
So when I'm going back and forth and back and forth I don't miss any of the action.
One final really, really quick note about basketball.
Elgin Baylor, the Hall of Famer let go by the Clippers, there may be some legal action.
The team has been a laughing stock for so long.
I'm going to just ask you really quickly, D-Will, in about 10 seconds.
Was this deserved do you think?
Yes.
Elgin Baylor's presided over a losing program for 20 years now.
It's about time a change was made.
That's too bad.
A great guy.
But the team, they suck.
There's just no way of putting it another way.
Greg Lee is an online sports writer for the Boston Globe.
He joined us from WBUR in Boston.
D-Will writes for the blog Sports on my Mind.
He came to us from the studios of KUT in Austin, Texas.
This is Day to Day, I'm Alex Cohen.
I am Alex Chadwick.
Coming up, the profile of the U.S.
badminton champions as they prepare for Beijing.
First though, banking giant Wachovia posted a surprising first quarter loss, nearly nine billion dollars.
That's a scary number, indeed.
But Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson says Americans should stay calm.
The American people have every reason to remain confident that the U.S.
banking system is sound.
The FDIC has made clear that of the nearly 8,500 insured banks and thrifts that comprise U.S.
banking system, 99 percent are well capitalized.
Paulson spoke earlier today in New York, where he also stressed the need for Congress to increase credit lines to the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
We're joined now by Phillip Swagel.
He's the assistant secretary for economic policy with the U.S.
Treasury Department, and if we could start off by talking about this plan to rescue Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
It could cost taxpayers as much as 25 billion dollars.
That's a lot of money.
Why should the government step in to help them out?

What Secretary Paulson discussed this morning is that the plan is there to make sure that the financial markets have the confidence that the two mortgage giants, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, will have the ability to continue to securitize and buy mortgages.
They're a very important source of finance to mortgage markets right now.
Markets have had concerns.
The plan is meant to be a backstop to them to say that there's liquidity support and capital support so they can continue to go on with their business.
And importantly, if the plan succeeds, and so far it does seem to be providing stability to the market, there won't be any cost to the government.
And this would be just a temporary measure, correct?
It will be for 18 months is what Secretary Paulson has asked for.
In a sense, he said he doesn't want the next administration to come in and have the situation where the capability that he needed is expiring on them.
Before this plan actually goes into effect, one of the steps it would need to happen is that treasury officials would look at the books of both Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
They're doing that now.
What exactly are they looking for and when might that process be done?
The Fed and Treasury are going in and looking at the books of the GSCsâ€¦
GSCs.
These are government sponsored enterprises, is that correct?
Yes, just because, of course, there's a disagreement, in a sense, between what the regulators see and what the market sees.
The market obviously has concerns about the quality of the assets on the GSC books, and that's why we're taking a second look.
Dr. Allan Prochazka surveyed the doctors.
He falls in line with the task force.
Craig Holman is a lobbyist for Public Citizen.

He says this bill does require members of Congress, their staffs and those in the executive branch to disclose stock transactions within 30 days, and to do so electronically, which is a huge improvement over the current once-a-year paper-filing system.
But...
It's just the minimum of what Congress has to do to address congressional insider trading.
Still good, but what a missed opportunity.
To include things like the political intelligence provision and another one that was removed that would have made it easier to prosecute public corruption.
Still, Congresswoman Louise Slaughter, a Democrat from New York who's been working on the STOCK Act for six years, calls it a major step forward.
REP.
LOUISE SLAUGHTER: I'm delighted it's passing.
I really am.
And one thing I know about being in the legislature is that you're not really defeated until you quit.
She and a colleague have already introduced a new bill aimed at the political intelligence industry.
She just hopes it doesn't take another six years.
Tamara Keith, NPR News, the Capitol.
President Obama has asked Ben Bernanke to stay on as chairman of the Federal Reserve, and if the Senate goes along, Bernanke will have another four years to help manage the country's economy.
To talk about the challenges he would face, we called David Wessel.
He's economics editor of The Wall Street Journal, a frequent guest on this program, and joins us now.
Good morning.
Good morning, Renee.
The economy looks like it might be possibly improving, certainly stabilizing.
What would Bernanke focus on, were he to stay on as Fed chair?
Well, your forecast is a good one.
It's pretty much the one that Ben Bernanke himself has made.
His problem now is to decide when is the right moment for him to raise interest rates and pull back some of this credit that he has injected in the economy during the crisis.
If he moves too soon, he risks pushing the economy back into recession.
That's something that the Fed did back in 1937 during the Great Depression.
He doesn't want to do that.
But if he waits too long, he risks an outbreak of inflation that he has vowed to avoid.
He also has, I think, a big challenge in maintaining the Fed independence to make that decision.
He's under a lot of criticism from Congress.
It's a real vote of affirmation from the president, of course, that's he's being reappointed.
But he needs to keep good relations with Congress and defend the Fed to the public so the Fed has the independence that he so greatly values.
And the White House just came out with new projections on the federal deficit.
It's at $9 trillion over the next decade - enormous deficits, if you go along with the estimate.
That's got to be something that people are thinking about.
How would Bernanke deal with that?
Right.
It's something that Bernanke really cannot avoid worrying about.
For one thing, the global investors now seem willing to lend the U.S.
government enormous amounts of money at relatively low interest rates.
This year's deficit is going to be higher as a fraction of all the goods and services we produce in the U.S.
than at any time since World War II.
As long as the foreign investors keep coming, that's great.

If they get sated, Mr. Bernanke may have to cope with the fact that long-term interest rates -which is what they charge us for lending us money - could rise, and that could hurt the economy when it's still weak.
Or it could push down the value of the dollar, which could lead to inflation.
It could lead Mr. Bernanke to raise interest rates prematurely.
Or it could provide a lot of juice for the economy.
If things start to come back, he may find that he has to raise rates to slow the economy because there's so much fiscal policy pushing it along.
Is it all about reacting, though, for Bernanke?
I mean, does he have any influence over the deficits?
Well, you know, that's a good question.
He doesn't directly, of course.
Deficits are about taxes and spending.
That's the province of the president and the Congress.
But in the past, the Fed chairman - especially one who's got a little bit of credibility - has had an enormous amount of influence on Congress.

If he goes up there and testifies in his second term as Fed chairman that you guys really need to do something about this, or if he helps maybe influence the tone of the political debate and says you can't avoid this, that in the past -with Alan Greenspan or with Paul Volcker - has had an influence, and I suspect that'll happen again.
And David, what do you make of the nine trillion estimate of future deficits?
Is that on the money?
Is it an underestimation?
